content:
To improve performance for bots that use the cross-lingual model, review our best practices.

Utterances are built from conversational phrases called utterances. Utterances represent variations of customer input for an intent.

Write high-quality utterances that vary in word length and structure. Make sure you use multiple words in utterances. Utterance quality is more important than quantity for the cross-lingual intent model.

Sample utterances for the intent “Check the status of an order”:

“What is the status of my order?”
“I’m checking up on my order, can you look up the status”
“I would like to know the status of an order I placed”
“Status of my order please”

Write utterances that clearly illustrate the customer’s goal or intention. Use actionable verbs, such as “look up,” “order,” and “update.” Include a noun that’s acted on, such as “order,” “password,” or “transactions.”

Make utterances short and to the point. We recommend keeping them under 150 characters.

Intents power your bot’s dialogs. Create distinct and focused intents. The model performs better when each intent-enabled dialog has different goals and utterances.

Sample intents:

Distinct: “Order Status” and “Cancel Order”
Too similar: “Order Status” and “Order Related”
Too broad: “Manage Order”

When you can’t break down an intent any further, include utterances that vary in word length and structure.

Test your intents and iterate with bot training. If the customer input doesn’t invoke the Confused dialog when expected, determine which intents are invoked incorrectly. Then revise those intents and their utterances to follow best practices.

If the customer input matches to the wrong intent, revise the correct and wrong intent to follow best practices. Remove low-quality utterances, including one-word utterances and similar utterances, and then retrain the model.
title: Improving Cross-Lingual Intent Model Performance in Service Cloud
